title: Hebrews Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Hebrews chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Hebrews Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Hebrews Chapter 2.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 2:1, why ought we to give more earnest heed to the things we have heard?
options: Lest at any time we should let them slip
Because they are difficult to understand
questions.correctAnswer: Lest at any time we should let them slip
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:1 instructs that we ought to give earnest heed so we do not let the teachings slip away.

questions.question: What was the nature of the word spoken by angels according to Hebrews 2:2?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:2 says the word spoken by angels was stedfast, meaning firm and reliable.

questions.question: Who initially spoke the great salvation mentioned in Hebrews 2:3?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:3 states that the great salvation was first spoken by the Lord.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 2:4, how did God bear witness to the message?
options: With signs, wonders, miracles, and gifts of the Holy Ghost
questions.correctAnswer: With signs, wonders, miracles, and gifts of the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:4 explains God bore witness with signs, wonders, miracles, and gifts of the Holy Ghost.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 2:5, to whom has God not put the world to come in subjection?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:5 states that God has not put the world to come in subjection to the angels.

questions.question: Who is made a little lower than the angels according to Hebrews 2:7?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:7 explains that man was made a little lower than the angels.

questions.question: What do we see Jesus crowned with, according to Hebrews 2:9?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:9 states Jesus was crowned with glory and honour.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 2:10, what was made perfect through sufferings?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:10 says the captain of their salvation was made perfect through sufferings.

questions.question: Who is not ashamed to call us brethren according to Hebrews 2:11?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:11 explains that He who sanctifies is not ashamed to call us brethren.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 2:14, why did Jesus take part in flesh and blood?
options: To destroy him that had the power of death, the devil
questions.correctAnswer: To destroy him that had the power of death, the devil
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:14 states Jesus took flesh and blood to destroy the devil who had power over death.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 2:15 says Jesus delivered those subject to bondage through fear of death.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:15 confirms Jesus delivered those who were in bondage through fear of death.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 2:16 states Jesus took on the nature of angels.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:16 clarifies Jesus did not take on the nature of angels but the seed of Abraham.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 2:18 says Jesus is able to help those who are tempted because He has suffered temptation Himself.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:18 states Jesus can help tempted people because He suffered being tempted.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Hebrews 2:12: 'I will declare thy name unto my ______, in the midst of the church will I sing praise unto thee.'
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:12 says, 'I will declare thy name unto my brethren...'

questions.question: According to Hebrews 2:17, why was Jesus made like His brethren?
options: To be a merciful and faithful high priest and make reconciliation for sins
To perform miracles among the people
questions.correctAnswer: To be a merciful and faithful high priest and make reconciliation for sins
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:17 states Jesus was made like His brethren to be a merciful and faithful high priest for reconciliation.

medium.title: Hebrews Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Hebrews Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is neglecting their spiritual growth and ignoring the teachings of Christ. Based on Hebrews 2, what biblical truth would you share about the importance of attention to God's word?
options: We must give the more earnest heed to the things we have heard to avoid losing our salvation.
It is acceptable to occasionally ignore God's word without consequence.
Angels are a better source of truth than Christ's teachings.
Salvation is guaranteed regardless of our attention to God's word.
questions.correctAnswer: We must give the more earnest heed to the things we have heard to avoid losing our salvation.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:1-3 emphasizes the necessity of paying earnest attention to the message of salvation to avoid neglecting it and losing the opportunity for salvation. Neglecting so great salvation leads to serious consequences.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 2 encourage believers to trust in God's power when facing trials?
options: God bears witness with signs, wonders, miracles, and gifts of the Holy Spirit.
Believers should rely solely on their own strength.
Trials mean God has abandoned us.
Miracles are no longer relevant in the Christian life.
questions.correctAnswer: God bears witness with signs, wonders, miracles, and gifts of the Holy Spirit.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:4 shows that God confirms His word through supernatural means, encouraging believers to trust His power and presence during trials.

questions.question: A believer feels small and insignificant in the vastness of the world. What does Hebrews 2 teach about God's view of humanity?
options: God is mindful of man and has crowned him with glory and honor.
Humans are unimportant and easily forgotten by God.
Angels are superior and more valued than humans.
Man is destined to remain under the power of death.
questions.correctAnswer: God is mindful of man and has crowned him with glory and honor.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:6-7 affirms God's care for humans, stating that man was made a little lower than angels and crowned with glory and honor, highlighting human dignity and God's mindfulness.

questions.question: Based on Hebrews 2, how should believers view Jesus’ suffering and death in relation to their own struggles?
options: Jesus was made lower than angels to suffer death so He could help those who are tempted.
Jesus’ suffering is unrelated to our daily struggles.
Jesus only suffered for the sins of the priests, not for all people.
Suffering is a sign of God's displeasure.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus was made lower than angels to suffer death so He could help those who are tempted.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:9 and 2:18 teach that Jesus shared in human suffering and death to become a merciful and faithful high priest who can assist those who face temptation and trials.

questions.question: A believer is fearful of death and feels bound by anxiety. According to Hebrews 2, what hope can you share?
options: Jesus destroyed the power of death through His own death, freeing believers from bondage.
Fear of death is unavoidable and eternal.
Only angels can overcome the fear of death.
Believers must earn freedom from death by good works.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus destroyed the power of death through His own death, freeing believers from bondage.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:14-15 explains that Jesus took on human flesh to destroy the devil's power over death and deliver those who were held in lifelong fear of death.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 2 explain the relationship between Jesus and believers in terms of family and fellowship?
options: Jesus calls believers 'brethren' and identifies with them closely.
Jesus remains distant and does not relate to believers.
Believers are servants but not family to Jesus.
Jesus only identifies with angels, not humans.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus calls believers 'brethren' and identifies with them closely.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:11 shows that Jesus sanctifies believers and calls them brethren, indicating a close familial relationship and fellowship.

questions.question: In Hebrews 2, what is the significance of Jesus being called the 'captain of our salvation'?
options: He leads believers to glory by being made perfect through suffering.
He is a military leader unrelated to salvation.
Salvation is earned by human effort alone.
The title refers only to angels.
questions.correctAnswer: He leads believers to glory by being made perfect through suffering.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:10 explains that Jesus, for whom all things exist, was made perfect through suffering to lead many to glory, emphasizing His role in salvation.

questions.question: True or False: According to Hebrews 2, Jesus took on the nature of angels to redeem humanity.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:16 clearly states that Jesus did not take on the nature of angels but took on the seed of Abraham, identifying fully with humanity.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 2 teaches that Jesus' ability to help those tempted comes from His own experience of suffering and temptation.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:18 states that because Jesus suffered being tempted, He is able to help those who are tempted, showing the practical comfort believers have in Him.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hebrews 2 teaches that Jesus was made like His brethren in all things so that He might be a _____ and faithful high priest.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:17 emphasizes Jesus' mercy and faithfulness as a high priest, highlighting His identification with humanity and His role in reconciliation.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 2 instruct believers regarding the seriousness of disobedience to God's word?
options: Every transgression and disobedience receives a just recompense of reward.
Disobedience is often overlooked by God.
Angelic words are less binding than human teachings.
Disobedience has no effect on salvation.
questions.correctAnswer: Every transgression and disobedience receives a just recompense of reward.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:2 warns that the word spoken by angels was steadfast, and every transgression and disobedience received just recompense, highlighting the seriousness of disobedience.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because they feel they lack spiritual gifts. What does Hebrews 2 say about the gifts of the Holy Spirit?
options: God gives gifts of the Holy Spirit according to His own will.
Spiritual gifts are only for the apostles.
Gifts of the Spirit are earned by works alone.
Holy Spirit gifts are no longer available.
questions.correctAnswer: God gives gifts of the Holy Spirit according to His own will.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:4 declares that God bears witness with gifts of the Holy Spirit, given according to His will, assuring believers that gifts come from God’s sovereign grace.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 2 challenge believers to view Jesus’ incarnation in terms of humility and identification with humanity?
options: Jesus was made a little lower than angels to identify with human suffering and death.
Jesus remained above human experience and did not suffer.
Jesus only appeared in human form but did not truly identify with humans.
Jesus was equal with angels and did not humble Himself.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus was made a little lower than angels to identify with human suffering and death.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:9 teaches that Jesus was made lower than angels temporarily to suffer death for every man, demonstrating humility and full identification with humanity.

questions.question: What practical lesson about perseverance during trials can be drawn from Hebrews 2's description of Jesus' sufferings?
options: Jesus was made perfect through sufferings, encouraging us to endure hardships for growth.
Suffering should be avoided at all costs.
Only those who suffer earn God's favor.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus was made perfect through sufferings, encouraging us to endure hardships for growth.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:10 highlights that Jesus was perfected through suffering to bring many to glory, teaching believers to view trials as part of spiritual maturity.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 2, how should believers respond to God's name within the church community?
options: Declare and sing praises to God's name among fellow believers.
Keep God's name private and avoid public praise.
Only priests should declare God's name.
Praise is unnecessary in the church community.
questions.correctAnswer: Declare and sing praises to God's name among fellow believers.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:12 instructs declaring God's name to brethren and singing praises in the church, encouraging active worship and fellowship.

hard.title: Hebrews Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Hebrews Chapter 2.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 2:2, what was the consequence for every transgression and disobedience under the word spoken by angels?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:2 states that every transgression and disobedience received a just recompense of reward under the word spoken by angels, emphasizing the seriousness of disobedience.

questions.question: What is the 'great salvation' mentioned in Hebrews 2:3 confirmed by?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:3 says that the great salvation was spoken by the Lord and confirmed unto us by those who heard Him, indicating eyewitness testimony as validation.

questions.question: Hebrews 2:4 mentions God bearing witness with several signs. Which of the following is NOT listed as one of those signs?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:4 lists signs, wonders, divers miracles, and gifts of the Holy Ghost but does not specifically mention tongue speaking.

questions.question: Hebrews 2:5 states that God has not put what under the subjection of angels?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:5 clearly states that God has not put the world to come under the subjection of angels, highlighting Christ's supremacy.

questions.question: In Hebrews 2:6-8, a quotation is used to emphasize man's position. Which Old Testament Psalm is referenced here?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:6-8 quotes Psalm 8, reflecting on man's position just below the angels and crowned with glory and honor.

questions.question: Hebrews 2:9 speaks of Jesus being made a little lower than the angels for what purpose?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:9 explains that Jesus was made a little lower than the angels to suffer death, so that by God's grace He might taste death for every man.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 2:10, what was made perfect through sufferings?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:10 states that it was fitting for the captain of salvation to be made perfect through sufferings, referring to Christ's redemptive work.

questions.question: What relationship between Jesus and believers is highlighted in Hebrews 2:11?
options: He is not ashamed to call them brethren
He is their high priest alone
He is their prophet and teacher
questions.correctAnswer: He is not ashamed to call them brethren
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:11 emphasizes that Jesus, who sanctifies, and those sanctified are all one, and He is not ashamed to call them brothers.

questions.question: Which two Old Testament quotations are combined in Hebrews 2:12-13 to emphasize Jesus' brotherhood with believers?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:12-13 cites Psalm 22:22 and Isaiah 8:17 to illustrate Jesus’ trust in God and His identification with His brethren.

questions.question: Hebrews 2:14 explains that Jesus took part in flesh and blood for what purpose?
options: To destroy the devil who had the power of death
questions.correctAnswer: To destroy the devil who had the power of death
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:14 states that Jesus partook of flesh and blood so that through death He might destroy the one holding the power of death, namely the devil.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 2:15, what bondage does Jesus deliver people from?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:15 explains that Jesus delivers those who were subject to bondage through fear of death their whole lifetime.

questions.question: Hebrews 2:16 states that Jesus did not take on the nature of angels but took on what instead?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:16 clarifies that Jesus assumed human nature, specifically the seed of Abraham, rather than angelic nature, emphasizing His identification with humanity.

questions.question: What was the purpose of Jesus being made like His brethren, according to Hebrews 2:17?
options: To be a merciful and faithful high priest
To abolish the Law of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: To be a merciful and faithful high priest
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:17 states that Jesus was made like His brethren to be a merciful and faithful high priest to make reconciliation for the sins of the people.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 2:18 describe Jesus' ability to help those who are tempted?
options: Because He Himself suffered being tempted
Because He was free from sin
Because He was worshiped by angels
questions.correctAnswer: Because He Himself suffered being tempted
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:18 explains that Jesus can help those tempted because He Himself suffered temptation, providing empathy and aid.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 2:1-4 warns against neglecting the salvation spoken by the Lord and confirmed by signs and wonders.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:1-4 warns believers to pay earnest heed to the salvation spoken by the Lord and confirmed by signs and wonders lest they drift away.

theological.title: Hebrews Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Hebrews Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 2, why should believers pay closer attention to the message they have heard?
options: To avoid letting the great salvation slip away
questions.correctAnswer: To avoid letting the great salvation slip away
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:1-3 emphasizes the urgency of heeding the gospel message to avoid neglecting the great salvation first spoken by the Lord. This aligns with warnings in 2 Corinthians 6:2 about not receiving God's grace in vain and James 1:22 about being doers of the word.

questions.question: What kind of recompense did every transgression and disobedience receive when the word was spoken by angels?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:2 states that the word delivered by angels was steadfast and that every violation received just recompense, highlighting God's justice consistent with passages like Romans 6:23 and Galatians 6:7.

questions.question: Who bore witness to the message of salvation with signs, wonders, and gifts of the Holy Spirit?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:4 explains that God bore witness through signs, wonders, miracles, and spiritual gifts, affirming divine authority similar to Acts 2:22 and Exodus 4:11-12 where God authenticates His word.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 2, to whom has God not subjected the world to come?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:5 states that God has not put the world to come in subjection under the angels, indicating a higher purpose for humanity, consistent with Psalm 8:4-6 and Colossians 1:16-17.

questions.question: In Hebrews 2, what was man made a little lower than?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:7 quotes Psalm 8:4-6 showing man was made a little lower than angels, crowned with glory and honor, illustrating mankind's dignity and role in creation, which is foundational to Christian anthropology.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus being made a little lower than the angels according to Hebrews 2?
options: To suffer death and be crowned with glory and honor
questions.correctAnswer: To suffer death and be crowned with glory and honor
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:9 reveals Jesus' incarnation as being made lower than angels to suffer death, thereby tasting death for all, a key Christological truth teaching the necessity of the incarnation and atonement (John 1:14, Philippians 2:6-8).

questions.question: Why was it fitting for Jesus to be made perfect through sufferings according to Hebrews 2?
options: To bring many sons to glory as the captain of salvation
questions.correctAnswer: To bring many sons to glory as the captain of salvation
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:10 states that Jesus' sufferings perfected him to lead many to glory, consistent with Isaiah 53:10 and Philippians 2:8-11, affirming Jesus' role as the pioneer of salvation through obedience and sacrifice.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 2, what relationship does Jesus have with those he sanctifies?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:11 teaches that Jesus is not ashamed to call those sanctified his brethren, emphasizing his identification with humanity, echoing Isaiah 8:17-18 and John 1:12-13.

questions.question: Which two Old Testament declarations does Hebrews 2 cite to express Jesus’ relationship with his brethren?
options: "I will declare thy name unto my brethren" and "I will put my trust in him"
"Fear not, for I am with you" and "The Lord is my shepherd"
"Behold, I make all things new" and "The Lord reigns"
"Thou art my Son" and "Let there be light"
questions.correctAnswer: "I will declare thy name unto my brethren" and "I will put my trust in him"
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:12-13 quotes Psalm 22:22 and Isaiah 8:17 to show Jesus’ intimate fellowship and trust in God alongside his brethren, affirming the messianic fulfillment and the unity of Christ with believers.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Jesus taking part in flesh and blood according to Hebrews 2?
options: To destroy the power of the devil through death
questions.correctAnswer: To destroy the power of the devil through death
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:14 explains that Jesus partook of flesh and blood to destroy the devil’s power by His death, which aligns with Colossians 2:15 and 1 John 3:8, highlighting Christ’s victory over sin and death.

questions.question: What bondage does Jesus deliver people from, as described in Hebrews 2?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:15 states that Jesus delivers those who were subject to lifelong bondage through the fear of death, resonating with 1 Corinthians 15:55-57 and Psalm 23:4, emphasizing liberation through Christ.

questions.question: What nature did Jesus not take on according to Hebrews 2?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:16 clarifies that Jesus did not take on angelic nature but took on the seed of Abraham, affirming his true humanity and fulfillment of God’s covenant with Abraham (Genesis 22:18, Galatians 3:16).

questions.question: Why was it necessary for Jesus to be made like his brethren according to Hebrews 2?
options: To be a merciful and faithful high priest making reconciliation for sins
questions.correctAnswer: To be a merciful and faithful high priest making reconciliation for sins
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:17 teaches Jesus’ full identification with humanity to serve as a compassionate high priest who reconciles sinners to God, consistent with Leviticus 16 and Hebrews 4:15.

questions.question: What enables Jesus to help those being tempted, according to Hebrews 2?
options: His own experience of suffering and temptation
questions.correctAnswer: His own experience of suffering and temptation
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:18 states that because Jesus suffered and was tempted, he is able to aid those facing temptation, a truth supported by James 4:7 and 1 Peter 5:8-9 about Christ’s empathy and power.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 2, who is the 'captain of their salvation'?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:10 calls Jesus the captain (pioneer) of salvation, highlighting his leadership in bringing many to glory, consistent with Acts 5:31 and Philippians 2:9-11.
